inlineContent.text: Note: if your experience “cannot load page” errors when navigating between entries in this documentation, then the culprit is very likely an activated ad blocker. Many of the documented classes and services have names related to advertising terms. We found that this can trigger ad blockers. So please disable your adblocker if you have issues.
To serve Advertisements using the Adition AdSDK you will typically
Add the package dependencies
Initialize and configure the AdService
Register Ad Renderers
Request Ads
Observe Ad state and events
Apps using this AdSDK must be built at least for deployment target of iOS 14.0.
For a step by step documentation for integrating the AdSDK with example code, please refer to the
To use the ADITION AdSDK the application developer will need to acquire the Ad SDK library as well as “networkId” and “contentUnitId” pairs from an ADITION customer.
Your App uses the AdSDK to request ads from the Adserver.
To enable the adserver to serve relevant ads, you can pass information when requesting ads:
Network ID (required) supplied when configuring the
using
When creating an
, you can pass additional information through
contentUnit (required)
profiles (optional)
keywords (optional)
windowId (optional)
When dealing with Ads you will interact with the following classes:
initial configuration
fetching advertisements
represents an advertisement
Represents the lifecycle states of an Advertisements (loading, caching, readyToPresent, error)
Represents tracking events triggered when an advertisement is served, displayed or users interact with it
AdView (SwiftUI)
while
represents the content and state of an advertisement,
is the element for displaying it.
AdView lives in a separate framework you need to import if your app uses SwiftUI:
add an
to your view hierarchy to display an advertisement
The network id and the content unit id will be required to
create Advertisements. The content unit id is a unique id and
is the id of an AdSDK Content Unit in the ADITION AdServing
Platform. Currently ADITION supports two kinds of AdSDK Content
Units, the fixed size and the variable size content units. The
fixed size content unit only allows banners to be placed if they
match the size of the fixed content unit width and height. The
variable size content unit allows banners to be placed if they
fall between a lower and upper width and height range.
When requesting an advertisement it is possible to send application targeting profiles which can be used to select the correct banner that should be delivered.
Profile targeting allows the developer to add key and value
pairs when creating an advertisement through
Profile targeting allows for complex targeting as one is able to set key and
value pairs for example (key,value) as (“gender”,“male”) and
(“activity”,“news”) which will allow a banner to match with
the profile expression “gender=‘male’ and activity=‘news’”.

code: guard case .failure(let error) = completion else { return }
guard let error = error as? AdError else { return }

inlineContent.text: Keys must match the following regular expression:
Values must match the following regular expression:
Other characters can not be guaranteed to work properly.
Additionally keys may only start with a character.
The SDK will validate that the given profile matches this criteria. In case the profile is invalid, an AdError will be created. See
The ADITION AdSDK provides functionality to organize window ids so that inclusion and exclusion filters can be evaluated.

Naturally, the window id does not expire after a specific time. Keep in mind though, that it can not be guaranteed for a window id to function properly after a waiting time of 60 seconds between requests with that same window id.
By default, every
you request creates a new window id.  To use the same window id, you can pass a value when creating an Advertisement object:

code: guard case .failure(let error) = completion else { return }
guard let error = error as? AdError else { return }

inlineContent.text: inApp-ClickURLs is a feature which allows you to specify
a custom schemed click url. An example of a custom scheme
url is
. Banners with this option
selected will not open a browser when it is clicked. If an app is installed on the device for the given URL schema, then this app will be opened to process the URL.
The ADITION click counting works by initially calling the
adserver url which will then count the click and redirect
to the banner click url. By default this is done by the
built-in ADITION browser. The exception to this default
click handling is with inApp-ClickURL banners, as they
are handled by the SDK internally which ensures the click
is successfully counted and the intent fired.
The keyword targeting is a simple comma separated list of keywords that can be used to make partial or complete keyword list targeting.
The keyword list can be set in
This targeting is generally useful for category and meta type targeting. Most campaigns will use profile targeting instead as it provides a syntactical targeting which is superior.
Tagging targeting is a server side tagging (user profile) feature. You are able to tag a user currently using your application with key = value tags that can be used
in targeting of campaigns within the ADITION adserving platform. A Tag in ADITION consists of a key and a value. The key is made up of 2 parts. The
attribute and the sub-attribute. An example of a tag could be:
The Tags can be setup on the adition server to keep all the tags or always overwrite with the last sent tag. Therefore it is possible to have a history or the most current tag value.
The client/app can fire the tag request as soon as an event or action occurs within the app. The AdDelivery requests made after a tag was sent will be able to use the
tags within the targeting.
See
Tag keys must match the following regular expression:
Tag values must match the following regular expression:
The SDK will validate that the given tags matches these criteria. In case tags are invalid, an AdError will be created. See
Tracking is a server side feature. You are able to perform tracking request to track your conversions. Track request contains the following parameters:
Required:
– Internal adserver backend ID for the posttracking landingpage.
– Internal adserver backend ID for the trackingspot.
Optional:
– Order ID, which is a purchase transaction ID.
– Item price.
– Overall turnover of the basket.
– Item number/quantity.
– ID of a purchased article(s).
– Item description.
The client/app can fire the track request as soon as a conversion occurs within the app. See
values must match the following regular expression:
The SDK will validate that this values matches these criteria. In case track request are invalid, an AdError will be created. See
Advertisements will emit two types of events:
Lifecycle events
Tracking events
- user triggered an URL, for example by tapping on an Ad
- the ad has been rendered, irregardless if it has been seen by the user or not. Can be triggered if the add is outside of the viewport
At least 1%/50%/100% of the Ad has been actually seen by the user
– signals that the renderer is currently showing a particular asset.
– signals that the renderer has passed a custom event.
To enable the partial visibility events
, you have to add the .adsContainer() modifier:
Which tracking events are enabled for which Advertisements is configured in the Adition Backend.
You can observe lifecycle and trackinge events easily:
